rows.title: Who Took My Shoe?

description.eng: Jabulani has lost his school shoe. He can’t find it anywhere. Where can it be?

text_1.eng:
“Come, Jabulani,” Ma says.“Why aren’t you ready? You’ll be late for school.”

“I can’t find my shoe,” says Jabulani.

text_2_left.eng:
“Did you look under your bed?” says Ma.
“It’s not under my bed,” Jabulani says.

text_2_right.eng:
“Did you look in the wardrobe?” Ma asks.

“Yes, it’s not in the wardrobe.”

text_3_left.eng:
“I know where your shoe is,” giggles Jabulani’s sister Lungi.

“Where?” Jabulani asks.

“I’m not telling you!” says Lungi

text_4_left.eng: “Why would someone take one shoe when they’ve got two feet?” says Lungi.

text_4_right.eng: “I don’t know. Maybe they’ve hidden it to make me cross.”

text_5_left.eng: “Did you take my shoe?” he asks Lungi.

text_5_right.eng: “No,” says Lungi, “your shoes are too big for me.”

text_6_left.eng: “Did you take my shoe?” Jabulani asks Fruit Juice the Dog.

text_6_right.eng: She smiles her big dog smile at him and wags her tail.

text_7.eng: “Maybe a bird picked it up and flew away with your shoe,” laughs Lungi.

text_8.eng: “Maybe a monkey took it and left it up in a tree, ” says Jabulani.

text_9.eng:
“Don’t worry, we’ll find your shoe,” says Ma.
“Everyone look for Jabulani’s shoe.”

But the shoe is nowhere to be found.

text_10.eng:
“It’s all right,” says Ma.
“You can wear your takkies to school today.”

text_11.eng:
Lungi comes rushing into the kitchen with a big smile on her face.

“I know where your shoe is,” she shouts. “Come and see.”

rows.title: A Very Important Tree

description.eng:
Busi loves the big, beautiful tree outside her house.
But her brother wants to cut it down.
How will she stop him?

rows.title: I don't want to go to sleep

title.eng: I don't want to go to sleep

description.eng: Nandi doesn’t want to go to sleep. No way! She wants to go on an adventure. Join Nandi as she lets her imagination run wild and free.

text_1_right.eng: “I don’t want to go to sleep!”

text_2_right.eng: “I ... don’t ... want ... to ... go ... to ... sleep."

text_3_left.eng:
“I want more supper.
Another book!
Just one more song?”

“Goodnight, Nandi.”

text_3_right.eng: “I don’t want to go to sleep!”

text_4_left.eng:
"MAMA!
...I need a glass of water.
Please?
Please."

“It’s time to go to sleep now.
Goodnight, Nandi.”

text_4_right.eng: “I DON’T WANT TO GO TO SLEEP!”

text_5_left.eng:
Mama sighs: “What about an adventure?
Do you want an adventure?”

text_6_left.eng: “Do you want to creep through the jungle on the trail of the fearsome hippocrocoturtleduck?”

text_7.eng:
“I want to fly across the sky!
Leap from star to star!
Fill my pocketswith stardust!”

text_8.eng: “I want a Nandi-sized glass submarine to see the creatures at the bottom of the ocean! And a pet giant squid to do water ballet there with me!”

text_9.eng: “I want to build myself a pair of butterfly wings and zoom to the roof of the sky where I’ll see all the world and everything in it!”

text_10.eng: “Look here, Nandi. Here is your very own adventure boat. It’s waiting to take you wherever you want to go. See, put your head here...that’s right...and I’ll just tuck you in...there we go...now, off you go! Adventure awaits ...”

rows.title: Scared Tumi

description.eng: “What if there’s a monster under my bed?” Tumi is scared. Mama tries to show him that everything is okay.

text_1.eng: My name is Tumi and I am scared.

text_2.eng: Mama says it’s okay to be scared. “Everybody gets scared.”

text_3.eng: What if there is a monster under my bed?

text_4.eng: “Then I will tell it to go away and NEVER come back.”

text_5.eng: What if there are eyes in the bath tub drain?

text_6.eng: “Then your big sister, Kamo, will pull you out of the bath.”

text_7.eng: What if a whale swallows me at the beach?

text_8.eng: “Then Kamo and I will swim into the whale’s mouth to rescue you.”

text_9.eng: What if I can’t sing ABC and the other kids laugh at me?

text_10.eng: “Then Teacher Jill will help you remember.”

text_11.eng: What if I'm scared of going to the dentist tomorrow?

text_12.eng:
“I will be right there holding your hand.” 
Everybody gets scared. Mama says it’s okay.

rows.title: Mom's Red Coat

description.eng: Mom needs to go away for work. I’ll miss her. Will it help if she leaves her red coat with me?

text_1.eng: I love Mom’s coat! It’s red and long and warm. And it smells like Mom!

text_2.eng:
I love doing things with Mom!
We picnic outside.
She hugs me when I come home from school.
We work in the garden.
At night, she holds me tight until I fall asleep.

text_3.eng: ‘Good news!’ says Mom. ‘I found a job! I will be away all week, but I’ll come home on weekends!’

text_4.eng: ‘Who will hold me at night, Mom?’ ‘Who will hug me, picnic with me, garden with me?’

text_5.eng:
‘I can see that you are sad. I will leave my red coat here with you.’ 
‘When you see it, remember that I love you and I’m coming back.’

text_6_left.eng:
I drag the red coat outside – it’s my 
picnic blanket! It feels like Mom is with me.

text_7.eng:
I am sad that Mom’s not waiting at the door 
when I come home. I put on her coat. It’s warm and it smells like her. It feels like a hug!

text_8.eng:
I help Gogo in the garden.
The long coat on the branch scares away the chickens!
It feels like Mom is gardening with us.
Oops! Mud!

text_9.eng:
When it’s dark, I miss Mom most. Gogo covers me with her warm coat. It feels like Mom is holding me as I fall asleep.
Oops! Cookie crumbs!

text_10.eng:
Mom’s red coat is warm and smells like...paint, juice, 
mud and cookie crumbs!
Oops! We need to wash it!

text_11.eng:
The wind blows the red coat off the washing line...up into the air! It flies over the fence! It flies over the taxi!
Oops! Who did the coat fall on?

text_12.eng: I run and grab it! ‘Found you, coat!’ The red coat smells like Mom again. ‘Oh!’ ‘Found you, Mom! You’re back!’

rows.title: When Will Amma Be Back?

description.eng: Roja’s mother leaves for work early in the day. She promises to be back by bedtime. What will Roja do all day without Amma?

text_1.eng:
Roja is sad. Amma is going to work. 
“I will be back before bedtime, kannamma,” says Amma.

text_2.eng:
“But at what time?” asks Roja. “At exactly 9 o’clock tonight,” replies Amma.
Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 6 o’clock in the morning.

text_3.eng: “I want Amma to give me milk. Not you!” says Roja to Appa. Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 8 o’clock in the morning.

text_4.eng: “Let’s buy potatoes, Thaatha!” says Roja. “But we had potatoes just yesterday. How about brinjal today?” Thaatha asks. Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 10 o’clock in the morning.

text_5.eng: “Paati, let’s eat. Thaatha is making pappadam!” Roja yells. Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 1 o’clock in the afternoon.

text_6.eng:
Honk! Honk! Roja’s Akka is back from school. “Paati says I will go to school with you after this summer. Won’t that be fun,Akka?” says Roja, excitedly.
Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 3 o’clock in the afternoon.

text_7.eng:
“It’s time to go home, Roja,” Appa calls out. “Just one last time!” shouts Roja.
Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 5 o’clock in the evening.

text_8.eng:
“Selvi, eat your dosai quickly! Only then will you become big and strong,” says Roja.
Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 7 o’clock at night.

text_9.eng: “And so, when the cap-seller threw down his cap, the monkeys threw their caps down too... ”

text_10.eng:
“AMMMAAAA!” Roja shouts. “What did you do all day, Roja?” Amma asks.
Tick tock! Tick tock! It is almost 9 o’clock at night.

text_11.eng: “I had a lot of fun today, Amma! Appa fed me breakfast. I bought brinjal with Thaatha. He made pappadam for lunch.

text_12.eng: I picked up Akka from the school van. I played in the park. I fed Selvi dinner. Appa told me a story and now you are back!” Roja says, with a wide smile.

text_13.eng:
Tick tock! Tick tock!
It is 9 o’clock at night!

text_14.eng:
**My Day**

Here are some things that Roja does at different times of the day. What did you do at the same time yesterday? 
Draw pictures of yourself doing these different things on a piece of paper.
1. Roja eats breakfast at 8 o’clock. What did you do at 8 o’clock yesterday?
2. Roja goes shopping at 10 o’clock. What did you do at 10 o’clock yesterday?
3. Roja eats lunch at 1 o’clock. What did you do at 1 o’clock yesterday?

text_15.eng:
4. Roja picks up Akka from the school van at 3 o’clock. What did you do at 3 o’clock yesterday?
5. Roja plays in the park at 5 o’clock. What did you do at 5 o’clock yesterday?
6. Roja feeds Selvi at 7 o’clock. What did you do at 7 o’clock yesterday?

Roja is sad. Amma is going to work.

rows.text_2:
“But at what time?” asks Roja. “At exactly 9 o’clock tonight,” replies Amma.
Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 6 o’clock in the morning.
rows.text_3: “I want Amma to give me milk. Not you!” says Roja to Appa. Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 8 o’clock in the morning.
rows.text_4: “Let’s buy potatoes, Thaatha!” says Roja. “But we had potatoes just yesterday. How about brinjal today?” Thaatha asks. Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 10 o’clock in the morning.
rows.text_5: “Paati, let’s eat. Thaatha is making pappadam!” Roja yells. Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 1 o’clock in the afternoon.
rows.text_6:
Honk! Honk! Roja’s Akka is back from school. “Paati says I will go to school with you after this summer. Won’t that be fun,Akka?” says Roja, excitedly.
Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 3 o’clock in the afternoon.
rows.text_7:
“It’s time to go home, Roja,” Appa calls out. “Just one last time!” shouts Roja.
Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 5 o’clock in the evening.
rows.text_8:
“Selvi, eat your dosai quickly! Only then will you become big and strong,” says Roja.
Tick tock! Tick tock! It is 7 o’clock at night.
rows.text_9: “And so, when the cap-seller threw down his cap, the monkeys threw their caps down too... ”
rows.text_10:
“AMMMAAAA!” Roja shouts. “What did you do all day, Roja?” Amma asks.
Tick tock! Tick tock! It is almost 9 o’clock at night.
rows.text_11: “I had a lot of fun today, Amma! Appa fed me breakfast. I bought brinjal with Thaatha. He made pappadam for lunch.
rows.text_12: I picked up Akka from the school van. I played in the park. I fed Selvi dinner. Appa told me a story and now you are back!” Roja says, with a wide smile.
rows.text_13:
Tick tock! Tick tock!
It is 9 o’clock at night!
rows.text_14:
**My Day**

Here are some things that Roja does at different times of the day. What did you do at the same time yesterday? 
Draw pictures of yourself doing these different things on a piece of paper.
1. Roja eats breakfast at 8 o’clock. What did you do at 8 o’clock yesterday?
2. Roja goes shopping at 10 o’clock. What did you do at 10 o’clock yesterday?
3. Roja eats lunch at 1 o’clock. What did you do at 1 o’clock yesterday?
rows.text_15:
4. Roja picks up Akka from the school van at 3 o’clock. What did you do at 3 o’clock yesterday?
5. Roja plays in the park at 5 o’clock. What did you do at 5 o’clock yesterday?
6. Roja feeds Selvi at 7 o’clock. What did you do at 7 o’clock yesterday?

rows.title: The Bee and the Elephant

description.eng:
An elephant tries to help a little lost bee find his home. Is it the
nest? The cave? Where does he live?

text_1.eng:
"I am lost," said Little Bee. "I cannot find my home!"
"Can you please help me, Mr. Elephant?"

text_2.eng: "Is this nest your home, Little Bee?" the elephant asked.

text_3.eng: "Oh no!" cried Little Bee. "This is a bird’s home."

text_4.eng: "Is this cave your home?" asked the elephant.

text_5.eng: "Oh no! This is a bat’s home."

text_6.eng: "Is this hive your home, Little Bee?"

text_7.eng: "Oh yes!" said Little Bee happily. "This is my home."

text_8.eng: "Thank you for helping me, Mr. Elephant."

rows.title: Reba Wants Ice Cream

description.eng: When Reba comes home, she realises that a shopkeeper has given her too much change. Should she tell the shopkeeper the truth?

text_1.eng: “Ice cream! Ice cream!” The shopkeeper called.

text_2.eng:
Reba ran to her mother. “Ma! Ma! I want ice cream!”
“Finish your homework first,” said Ma.

text_3.eng:
Reba looked unhappy. Ma asked, “Are you done with your homework yet?”
“Mmm...No. But my notebook is full! I need to buy another one.”

text_5.eng:
Ma gave Reba 50 taka*. “Go buy a notebook. We also need a bar of soap.”
*Taka is the name of currency used in Bangladesh.

text_6.eng: Reba went to the shop. The shopkeeper gave Reba a notebook and a bar of soap. “How much?” asked Reba.

text_8.eng: “The notebook is 20 taka, and the soap is 20 taka,” said the shopkeeper. “That means the total cost is 40 taka. Here’s your change.”

text_9.eng: When Reba came back home, she calculated her change.Reba gave the shopkeeper 50 taka. The notebook was 20 taka, and the soap was 20 taka.

text_10.eng: “I should only get 10 taka back,” thought Reba. “Why did the shopkeeper give me 20 taka back?”

text_11_left.eng: “That's great!” thought Reba. “I can buy ice cream with this extra money!”

text_11_right.eng: But Reba was ashamed of herself. “I should go back and give the shopkeeper the correct change.”

text_12.eng: Reba rushed back to the shop. There were so many kinds of ice creams that she wanted! “Oh, if only I could have an ice-cream!” she thought.

text_13.eng:
When Reba got to the shop, she saw another girl who had just bought ice cream. She was about to go home.
The shopkeeper stopped her. “Wait!” he said. “You've given me too much money. Come back, take the change.”

text_14.eng: The shopkeeper gave the girl her change. Reba stepped forward. “You gave me 10 extra taka. Please take your money back.”

text_15.eng: “You’re such an honest girl!” The shopkeeper was so happy with Reba’s honesty that he gave her an ice cream for free! Reba happily licked her ice cream all the way home.

rows.title: Rani's First Day at School

description.eng: What does Rani see on her first day in school? How does she feel?

text_1.eng: It is my first day at school. Mummy is holding my hand and walking with me. "I am grown up now," I say. "Let go, let go!" Mummy holds my hand very tight.

text_2.eng: There are many children near the school. They come by bus. They come by car. They come by rickshaw. They cycle. They walk, like me.

text_3.eng: We reach the gate. Mummy lets go of my hand. She stays at the gate. I have to go inside alone. There are many new faces all around me.

text_4.eng: I take one step. I take another step. I look back. Mummy gets smaller as I walk away. Will she disappear? I run back to her. I don’t feel so grown up. I hold her hand. “Don’t go away,” I say.

text_5.eng: Everyone is inside now. I am the only one outside. The teacher comes out. She smiles at me. I smile back. Mummy says, "Rani, I will be here when you come out."I let go of her hand. She waves to me.

text_6.eng: I run inside. Mummy will be there after school!

rows.text_2: There are many children near the school. They come by bus. They come by car. They come by rickshaw. They cycle. They walk, like me.

rows.text_4: I take one step. I take another step. I look back. Mummy gets smaller as I walk away. Will she disappear? I run back to her. I don’t feel so grown up. I hold her hand. “Don’t go away,” I say.
rows.text_5: Everyone is inside now. I am the only one outside. The teacher comes out. She smiles at me. I smile back. Mummy says, "Rani, I will be here when you come out."I let go of her hand. She waves to me.
rows.text_6: I run inside. Mummy will be there after school!

rows.title: Ma! Hurry Up!!

description.eng: The boy in the story is in a real hurry. Wouldn’t you like to find out why?

text_1.eng: I wake up in the morning. I rub my eyes. I cannot see my mother. “Ma! Ma! Hurry up!!”

text_2.eng: Ma is busy. She says, “Good morning. Get up! Go wash your face.”

text_3.eng: I wash my hands and face. I have a bath in a hurry. I want to go soon. “Ma, hurry up.”

text_4.eng: “Yes! I am coming,” Ma says to me. “I have to boil the milk, then I will come.”

text_5.eng: I comb my hair and button my shirt. Now I am ready. “Ma, hurry up.”

text_6.eng: Ma gives Didi her clothes. She helps Didi get ready. There is so much work in the morning. But I am in a hurry.

text_7.eng: “Ma, I am getting late.” I pick up my water bottle and school bag. I wear my chappals. “Come on let us go. Ma, hurry up.”

text_8.eng: ”Yes! I am coming. Let me comb your sister’s hair. I need five minutes more and then we can go.”

text_9.eng: I want to go now. I do not want to wait. I feel like crying. Didi has gone to school and I am still here.

text_10.eng: “I am almost done. I only have to fill water.” She always has something to do. “Ma, please, please, hurry up.”

text_11.eng: “I am going. You better come with me.” I hold her hand and start pulling her. “Arre baba, let me switch off the lights.”

text_12.eng:
Finally we are out of the house. Mother locks the door. She says, “Why are you so impatient,
my Raja?” I like it when she calls me ‘my Raja’. Now my mother is walking with me. I like that!!

rows.title: Katiiti’s Song

description.eng: Every day, Katiiti’s mother calls her with a beautiful song. One day, a crafty gorilla tries to sing as sweetly as her mother.

text_1.eng: Katiiti lived in a village next to a forest.

text_2.eng: She loved playing in the forest. Maama told her to be careful.

text_3.eng: Every day Maama would sing their special song to call her.

text_4.eng: One day, Katiiti bumped into a gorilla.

text_5.eng: She ran and hid in a cave.

text_6.eng: Gorilla came and sang Maama’s song in a gruff voice.

text_7.eng: Gorilla ate lots of bananas to make his voice sweeter.

text_9.eng: Gorilla went away and ate lots of honey to make his voice even sweeter.

text_10.eng: Gorilla sang as sweetly as Maama.

text_11.eng: Maama came just in time to chase away Gorilla.

text_12.eng: Katiiti and Maama sang all the way back home.
